title: $200 Billion Industry Nobody Is Talking About
transcript: So, in the first clip today, we're going to see why humanoid robots are about to become a $200 billion market, and it comes down to something most people don't think about, which is demographics. Then in clip two, we have an example from CNBC when one of the analysts builds an AI powered financial dashboard in minutes with zero coding experience. And we'll talk about what that means for anyone who wants to build something but never had a technical skill to do it, which is vibe coding, which is something I've been doing a lot of recently, too. And last up, we got a bonus clip from Jensen Huang, and that one is my favorite clip of the three. >> There's the $200 billion market forecast, but you identified two or three key factors about why you now see the commercial viability. What are those factors? Hello and good morning and thanks for having me on the show. AI is indeed getting very physical and I think humanoid robots are at the forefront of this trend. But I think the reason why um the proposition is changing and why there's going to be demand for these robots is because the demographics of uh the world population is changing. The reality is that um humans are getting older. I think by 2050 uh the share of people aged above 65 is going to double. Also, humans don't really want to live in rural areas anymore. They want to be based in cities, but the factories and the manufacturing facilities are actually located outside of these cities, which creates a bit of a structural issue. And then let's not forget that um workers preferences are changing. So which means that there will be certain essential jobs yet undesirable where which might not be filled and I think this is precisely where humanoids enter the picture. I think they could be taking on these repetitive jobs this dull dirty potentially dangerous jobs augmenting productivity and um producing efficiency gains for the industry as a whole. the the main players in this field talk a lot about the labor shortage in particular in manufacturing and heavy industry. You're saying it's going to be a $200 billion uh market by 2035. Do in your research do you have any sense of how real the market is today? How many humanoids are actually out there in uh manufacturing contexts around the world in present day? The the reality is that I think that humanoid robots are no longer confined to research labs. They're stepping out of the lab and they're getting into the real economy into the real world. Um they are um a couple thousand humanoid robots already deployed on factory floors uh doing actual work in manufacturing which I think is a natural starting place because these are jobs that are more structured more easily defined. So it is the place to start for humanoids. Uh but I think this is going to change in the next five to 10 years as the technology matures and as this market picks up space. So I think I wouldn't be surprised that by 2045 when we actually project that the humanoids market is going to be as big as 200 billion dollars um that we will see tens of thousands potentially even millions of humanoid robots. It's January again and by now you've started making resolutions to make the new year better for you. But the smartest people are already on the road to master that one skill that matters most in 2026. AI. Humanoid robots solve a workforce problem that no amount of hiring or immigration can fix. the world is running out of people willing to do essential jobs. So the demographics piece is actually one of the most important pieces of this entire conversation and it is actually something which gets overlooked when people debate whether robots are good or bad for jobs. By 2050 the share of people over 65 is going to double. Japan is already at 30%. And it's not just that people are getting older, it's that younger people don't want to work in factories anymore. They want to live in cities. They want knowledge work. They want to sit at a desk and do something on a computer. The manufacturing jobs, the warehouse jobs, the dangerous and repetitive stuff. Those positions are going unfilled right now. Tesla's been proving out this in real time with Optimus. They've got humanoids working on their own factory floors, doing pick and place tasks, taking parts from one spot and moving them to another. Sounds simple, but here's the thing. These are jobs that humans at Giga Shanghai decided they couldn't automate with a fixed robot arms. Task requires too much flexibility. You need something that can adapt to slight variations, reach awkward angles, handle unexpected situations. That's exactly what humanoid form factors are built for. And Tesla can test thousands of Optimus units internally for ever selling one to another company. They are their own first customer with millions of potential deployment positions. And the China dynamic here is fascinating, too. China's building out a massive humanoid supply chain right now. Dozens of companies, tens of billions of dollars pouring in. But there's a crucial difference between building hardware and building intelligence. You can manufacture a humanoid body, but can you train it to actually be useful in unpredictable environments? Tesla's advantage is they've been building physical AI for years with FSD. the same neural net architecture, the same training infrastructure, the same approach to realworld data collection. They're not starting from scratch on the intelligence piece. They've already solved the hard part in a different domain. And the economic math is pretty straightforward once you think it through. Minimum wage in the US hovers around 10 to 15 bucks per hour depending on the state.
